flow.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a smooth steady movement of liquid, gas, or electricity
flow.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I tied a towel round his leg to try to stem the flow of blood.
He struggled to swim against the flow of the water.
flow.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: a new road system to improve traffic flow through the city centre
flow.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the movement of goods, people, or information from one place to another
flow.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: They have accused the government of trying to block the free flow of information.
an attempt to stem the flow of refugees across the border
the flow of funds from the US to Europe
There has been a steady flow of people leaving the area.
flow.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: the continuous stream of words or ideas when someone is speaking, writing, or thinking about something
flow.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I didn’t want to interrupt her flow, so I said nothing.
flow.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the regular movement of the sea towards the land
flow.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: the ebb and flow of the tide
flow.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: when a liquid, gas, or electricity flows, it moves in a steady continuous stream
flow.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: If the windows are shut, air cannot flow freely through the building.
These gates regulate the amount of water flowing into the canal.
flow.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if goods, people, or information flow from one place to another, they move there in large numbers or amounts
flow.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Money has been flowing into the country from Western aid agencies.
The number of refugees flowing into the area is still increasing.
flow.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if traffic flows, it moves easily from one place to another
flow.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The new one-way system should help the traffic to flow better.
flow.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if alcohol flows at a party, people drink a lot and there is a lot available
flow.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Beer and whisky flowed freely as the evening wore on.
flow.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: if conversation or ideas flow, people talk or have ideas steadily and continuously, without anything stopping or interrupting them
flow.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Everyone was relaxed and the conversation flowed freely.
flow.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: when the sea flows, it moves towards the land
flow.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: We watched the tide ebb and flow.
flow.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: if a feeling flows through you or over you, you feel it strongly
flow.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: She felt hot rage flowing through her.
flow.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: if clothing or hair flows, it falls or hangs loosely and gracefully
flow.translation[1].definitions[7].examp: Her long hair flowed down her back.
flow.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: flow
if liquid flows, it moves in a steady continuous stream
Blood flowed from his hand.
The river flows very quickly at this point.
to flow – used when saying that something flows in a particular direction
Water was running down the walls of the room.
Sweat ran off his nose.
The river runs into the sea.
come out
to flow out of something
You couldn't drink any of the water that came out of the tap.
to flow in large quantities
The rain poured down.
Blood was pouring from a wound on his head.
gush
to flow out quickly in very large quantities
Water was gushing out at more than 3000 gallons a minute.
spurt
to flow out suddenly with a lot of force
Oil was spurting from a small hole in the pipe.
trickle
to flow slowly in drops or in a thin stream
Clare felt sweat trickling down the back of her neck.
leak
to flow in or out through a small hole or crack, usually when this is not meant to happen
Oil was leaking from the engine.
ooze
to flow from something very slowly – used about blood or a thick liquid
Blood was oozing from the wound.
Jam oozed out as she bit into the cake.
drip
to fall in drops
Water dripped from the tap continuously.
cascade
to flow down the side of something in large amounts
Water cascades down the hillside.
flow.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if money flows somewhere, such as into a bank account or into a particular country, it is moved there
flow.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: A record $10 billion in foreign capital flowed into Mexican stocks last year.
Throughout the summer, new savings flowed away from building society accounts.
Investment trust money has been flowing back into blue chip companies such as Sony and Honda.
flow.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if an event or action flows from something, it is caused by it
flow.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The regulations which flowed from the Charities Act forced charities to improve their accounts.
flow.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: if information or ideas flow, people start to exchange information or their ideas so that they can discuss them
flow.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: The meeting was relaxed and suggestions soon started to flow.
